title: Publications
text:
I keep my Orcid and Google Scholar relatively up to date.

Journal articles
* denotes joint first-author status.
Yeom, D., Haslam, N., Tan, Y. T., McPherson, G. E., & Wilson, S. J. (2024). Twin data support a sensitive period for singing ability. Twin Research and Human Genetics, 27(4-5), 204-214. https://doi.org/10.1017/thg.2024.30
Yeom, D., * Stead, K. S., * Tan, Y. T., McPherson, G. E., & Wilson, S. J. (2023). Self-evaluations of singing ability are accurate. Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences, 1530(1), 87-95. https://doi.org/10.1111/nyas.15081
Yeom, D., Tan, Y. T., Haslam, N., Mosing, M. A., Yap, V. M. Z., Fraser, T., McPherson, G. E., Hildebrand, M. S., Berkovic, S. F., Peretz, I., & Wilson, S. J. (2022). Genetic factors and shared environment contribute equally to objective singing ability. iScience, 25(6), 104360. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.isci.2022.104360



Book chapters
Coming soon…



Conference papers and posters
McKenzie, S., Glasser, S., Osborne, M., & Yeom, D. (2024, July 2-4). Sounds of compassion: An analysis of Spotify data [Conference presentation]. 12th European Society for the Cognitive Sciences of Music (ESCOM12), Melbourne, Australia.
Krause, A. E., Yeom, D., Osborne, M., & Glasser, S. (2024, July 2-4). Can we categorise listeners? A latent profile analysis [Conference presentation]. Australian Music and Psychology Society (AMPS) annual conference, Melbourne, Australia.
Yeom. D., Peretz, I., Tan, Y. T., Mosing, M. A., Hildebrand, M. S., Berkovic, S. F., McPherson, G. E., & Wilson, S. J. (2024, June 13-16). Perceptual and vocal pitch matching demonstrate genetic pleiotropy in Australian twins [Poster presentation]. The 8th meeting of The Neurosciences and Music, Helsinki, Finland.
Hughes, B., Yeom, D., & Mathur, A. (2023, July 20-22). What finger movements reveal about braille reading: The case of regressions [Conference presentation]. Society for the Scientific Study of Reading Conference, Port Douglas, Queensland, Australia.
Yeom, D., Haslam, N., Tan, Y. T., & Wilson, S. J. (2022, September 28). Testing the latent structure of singing ability [Conference presentation]. Australian Music and Psychology Society (AMPS) annual conference, online.
Yeom, D., McPherson, G. E., Hildebrand, M. S., Berkovic, S. F., Peretz, I., & Wilson, S. J. (2021, July 28-31). A critical systematic literature review of the genetic basis of music ability [Conference presentation]. 16th International Conference on Music Perception and Cognition and the 11th European Society for the Cognitive Sciences of Music (ICMPC16-ESCOM11), online.
Yeom, D., Lines, D. K., & Kirk, I. J. (2019, November 29 – December 1). No consistent evidence for frontal alpha asymmetry differences between musicians and controls: An exploration of state-trait dynamics in the emotional processing of music [Conference presentation]. KiwiCAM VIII, Auckland, New Zealand.
Yeom, D., Lines, D. K., & Kirk, I. J. (2019, July). Frontal alpha asymmetry, musical emotions and the role of expertise [Poster presentation]. 7th International Symposium of Performance Science (ISPS), Melbourne, Australia.

title: Daniel Yeom
text:
I’m the lab manager of the Clinical and Music Neuroscience Lab in the Melbourne School of Psychological Sciences, The University of Melbourne. I also recently completed my PhD in the school.
My research focuses around the behavioural genetics of human musicality - that is, the various behavioural and cognitive traits that influence our capacity to be musical, in all of its forms. I’m also interested in how to phenotype and measure individual differences in musicality.
This page is a work in progress but I hope to add to it soon! I recently switched over from using Bookdown + Hugo to Quarto for this website, so things are still missing from this new page.
You can learn more about me here.

title: About Dan
text:
I am a South Korean-born, Aotearoa New Zealand-raised researcher in music science. I completed a conjoint BSc/BMus at the University of Auckland, and a BSc (Hons) in psychology after that. I then moved to the University of Melbourne to pursue a PhD in the Melbourne School of Psychological Sciences.

Education







2020 - 2024
Doctor of Philosophy
Melbourne Schoool of Psychological Sciences, Faculty of Medicine, Dentistry and Health Sciences, University of Melbourne
Supervisors: Prof. Sarah WIlson, Prof. Gary McPherson, A/Prof. Margaret Osborne
Thesis title: Genetic and environmental influences on singing ability


2019
Bachelor of Science (Hons) in Psychology, First Class
School of Psychology, Faculty of Science, University of Auckland
Supervisors: Prof. Ian Kirk, A/Prof. David Lines


2015 - 2018
Bachelor of Science (Psychology), Bachelor of Music (Musicology/Music Education)
University of Auckland
